A Bitcoin maximalist that created a shitcoin.
Fought for UASF and dispelled FUD on Twitter. It takes all of us to stand up and make cryptocurrency antifragile.

Oh yeah, and let's not forget the 250BTC bet I had with Roger against Segwit2x. I've done more for Bitcoin than most people. So quite tired of getting attacked by Bitcoin maximalists. You and others have done a lot also, but we are in the same boat.

I think I've had enough of this conversation. I've put $1MM on the line of my own personal money for the sole purpose of helping Bitcoin activate SegWit. I don't need to take shit from people about it.
If one miner/pool didn't, another would have. And there was no guarantee that Bitcoin would get SegWit. Game theory would make it such that some miner/pool would steal the $1MM if they could.
Which ones? Tell me one that had a high enough marketcap with enough liquidity that could handle $1MM. Litecoin also had the closest mining ecosystem to Bitcoin.

I can't say for others, but I created Litecoin not to get rich quick. I would just be as well off today had I not created Litecoin. I created more for fun and because I think Litecoin can complement Bitcoin. And also found out later that Litecoin can help Bitcoin out with SegWit.

Did you forget the anyone-can-spend FUD? If there was a way for miners to steal from SegWit, they wouldn't reveal it on testnet. But having $1MM sitting there on Litecoin SegWit address for months shows that miners can't just steal that money.
And Litecoin is comparable. Less censorship-resistance for less cost. Comparable to less reliable for more efficient packets and faster communication.

I would also argue that Litecoin and others improve the censorship-resistance of cryptocurrency in general. If there was only Bitcoin, it becomes very easy for governments to take it down. But knowing that there will be others to take over makes cryptocurrency antifragile.
I would argue that Litecoin helped Bitcoin get SegWit faster by dispelling the SegWit FUD. It has not slowed down the adoption of Bitcoin.
I've always said that Litecoin complements Bitcoin and doesn't replace it.

It's hard for people who's not in my shoes to understand. Given that I created Litecoin, my skin in the game is more about pride, respect, and accomplishment than financial. It's something money can't buy, so it's much more than just having money in the game.
No, altcoins aren't pointless and I didn't create Litecoin to make money.
To take a page from Roger's book, I was a millionaire before Bitcoin. And I've held much more in BTC than LTC and have been public about that since the beginning.

Some people think Litecoin played a huge role. Some think it was a small thing that helped a bit. To say that Litecoin played no role and that testnet was enough means that you don't understand UASF and game theory. Hard to believe that for someone who wrote a book on Bitcoin.

You're wrong. Testnet coins don't have value, so there weren't incentives to attack it. When Litecoin had SegWit with $1MM bounty on a SegWit address with no one able to steal those anyone-can-spend coins, that showed that it was all FUD. Sad that you didn't see that.

Block-lattice data structure has nothing to do with lattice-based cryptography.
No, the "block-lattice" is just a data structure - it has nothing to do with lattice-base cryptography. Nano still uses elliptic curve.

This is a pretty bold claim RE: the impact of quantum computing on present day encryption. SHA-3 claims to be "post quantum sufficient", but are any cryptocurrencies currently experimenting with lattice-based cryptography? https://www.zdnet.com/article/ibm-warns-of-instant-breaking-of-encryption-by-quantum-computers-move-your-data-today/ …pic.twitter.com/HFRI77zmHP

Fin/ Ultimately, highly decentralized networks like Bitcoin offer a fertile foundation for economic growth in the digital world and will likely be important underpinnings of our increasingly digital economy.

10/ In this way, the Bitcoin network is a decentralized institution that defines, monitors, and enforces property rights. It is a reliable foundation of strong assurances on top of which we can efficiently architect arbitrary degrees of complexity.

9/ The Bitcoin network, for example, offers a self-contained, reliable foundation for property rights in a digital world. It is a rules-based, self-arbitrating court where valid transactions are clearly defined, objectively verifiable, and unerringly enforced.

2/ Symbolically, the Magna Carta marked a long-standing movement toward broad-based rule-of-law, and people’s rights. Now, highly decentralized networks like Bitcoin are picking up where our political institutions left off.

The transition to crypto anarchy is quite confusing; expect it to get worse before it gets better. Beware those who present themselves (or others) as authorities. Don't accept any single signal as objective truth, even if it's convenient to do so.
There is no objective metric; the human consensus of identifying Bitcoin is subjective, though the markets do a pretty good job of it.

Bitcoin Core is no more the True Bitcoin than Bitcoin Cash. Bitcoin is Bitcoin; there are clients that are compatible with the Bitcoin network and there are clients that are incompatible with the Bitcoin network.
Well, Bitcoin is far more than just blockchain, which is why it's probably not a great comparison to say "DAG" vs "Bitcoin" - it's the consensus mechanisms that really make the difference.
